page.title: List of Nobel Laureates affiliated with the University of Rochester

revision.text:
Established in 1895 by [[Alfred Nobel]], the [[Nobel Prize|Nobel Prizes]] are awarded annually to individuals who have made an outstanding contribution to the fields of [[chemistry]], [[physics]], [[literature]], [[peace]], or [[physiology]] or [[medicine]]<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://www.nobelprize.org/nobel_prizes/facts/|title=Nobel Prize Facts|website=www.nobelprize.org|access-date=2017-10-09}}</ref>. In 1968, the central bank of [[Sweden]], [[Sveriges Riksbank]], established the [[Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Sciences]]<ref name=":0" />. Laureates are selected by distinct committees: the physics, chemistry, and [[economics]] prizes are awarded by the [[Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences]]; physiology or medicine prize by the [[Karolinska Institute]], peace prize by the [[Norwegian Nobel Committee]].
As of October 2018, there are twelve Nobel laureates associated with the [[University of Rochester]]: two received their undergraduate degrees, five laureates received their advanced degrees, and five laureates were members of the faculty<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://rochester.edu/aboutus/pride.html|title=Points of Pride|website=rochester.edu|language=en|access-date=2017-10-09}}</ref>.

Economics Department|Faculty]], 1980s |"for integrating technological innovations into long-run macroeconomic analysis"<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nobelprize.org/prizes/economics/2018/summary/|title=The Prize in Economic Sciences 2018|website=www.nobelprize.org|access-date=2018-10-08}}</ref> |- |2018 |[[File:Gérard Mourou (cropped).jpg|thumb]] |[[Gérard Mourou]] |Physics |[[Laboratory for Laser Energetics|Faculty]], 1980s |"for their method of generating high-intensity, ultra-short optical pulses"<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=https://www.nobelprize.org/prizes/physics/2018/summary/|title=The Nobel Prize in Physics 2018|website=www.nobelprize.org|access-date=2018-10-08}}</ref> ([[chirped pulse amplification]]) |- |2018 |[[File:Donna Strickland - 2017 (cropped).jpg|thumb]] |[[Donna Strickland]] |Physics |Ph.D., 1989 |"for their method of generating high-intensity, ultra-short optical pulses"<ref name=":1" /> (chirped pulse amplification) |- |2017 |[[File:Richard Thaler Chatham.jpg|thumb]] |[[Richard Thaler]] |Economics |Ph.D., 1974 |"for his contributions to behavioural economics"<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nobelprize.org/prizes/economics/2017/summary/|title=The Prize in Economic Sciences 2017 |website=www.nobelprize.org|access-date=2018-10-08}}</ref> |- |2002 |[[File:Masatoshi Koshiba 2002.jpg|thumb]] |[[Masatoshi Koshiba]] |Physics |Ph.D., 1955 |“for pioneering contributions to astrophysics, in particular for the detection of cosmic neutrinos”<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nobelprize.org/prizes/physics/2002/summary/|title=The Nobel Prize in Physics 2002|website=www.nobelprize.org|access-date=2018-10-08}}</ref> |- |1997 |[[File:Steven Chu official DOE portrait.jpg|thumb]] |[[Steven Chu]] |Physics |B.A., B.S., 1970 |"for development of methods to cool and trap atoms with laser light."<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nobelprize.org/prizes/physics/1997/summary/|title=The Nobel Prize in Physics 1997|website=www.nobelprize.org|access-date=2018-10-08}}</ref> |- |1993 |[[File:Robert William Fogel.jpg|thumb]] |[[Robert Fogel]] |Economics |[[University of Rochester Economics Department|Faculty]], 1960s and ’70s |"for having renewed research in economic history by applying economic theory and quantitative methods in order to explain economic and institutional change"<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nobelprize.org/prizes/economics/1993/summary/|title=The Prize in Economic Sciences 1993|website=www.nobelprize.org|access-date=2018-10-08}}</ref> |- |1976 |[[File:Daniel Carleton Gajdusek 2bw.jpg|thumb]] |[[Daniel Carleton Gajdusek|D.Carleton Gajdusek]] |Physiology or Medicine |B.S., 1943 |"for their discoveries concerning new mechanisms for the origin and dissemination of infectious diseases"<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nobelprize.org/prizes/medicine/1976/summary/|title=The Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine 1976|website=www.nobelprize.org|access-date=2018-10-08}}</ref> |- |1959 |[[File:Arthur Kornberg (30828410210).jpg|thumb]] |[[Arthur Kornberg]] |Physiology or Medicine |M.D., 1941 |"for their discovery of the mechanisms in the biological synthesis of ribonucleic acid (RNA) and deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA)"<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nobelprize.org/prizes/medicine/1959/summary/|title=The Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine 1959|website=www.nobelprize.org|access-date=2018-10-08}}</ref> |- |1955 |[[File:Vincent du Vigneaud.jpg|thumb]] | [[Vincent du Vigneaud]] |Chemistry |Ph.D., 1927 |"for his work on biochemically important sulphur compounds, especially for the first synthesis of a polypeptide hormone"<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nobelprize.org/prizes/chemistry/1955/summary/|title=The Nobel Prize in Chemistry 1955|website=www.nobelprize.org|access-date=2018-10-08}}</ref> |- |1943 |[[File:Henrik Dam nobel.jpg|thumb]] | [[Henrik Dam]] |Physiology or Medicine |Senior research associate, 1942-1945 |''"''for his discovery of vitamin K"<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nobelprize.org/prizes/medicine/1943/summary/|title=The Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine 1943|website=www.nobelprize.org|access-date=2018-10-08}}</ref> |- |1934 |[[File:George Whipple nobel.jpg|thumb]] |[[George Whipple|George H. Whipple]] |Physiology or Medicine |Faculty, founding dean of [[University of Rochester Medical Center|School of Medicine and Dentistry]], 1921-1954 | "for their discoveries concerning liver therapy in cases of anaemia"<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nobelprize.org/prizes/medicine/1934/summary/|title=The Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine 1934|website=www.nobelprize.org|access-date=2018-10-08}}</ref> |}
